March 16, 2003: Fiction
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A public defender
in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy involving one of the largest
pharmaceutical companies in the world.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
SOMEONE TO WATCH OVER ME, by Judith McNaught. (Atria, $25.) When the
rich husband of a Broadway actress disappears, she becomes a suspect.
THE LAST DETECTIVE, by Robert Crais. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The Los Angeles
private eye Elvis Cole searches for his girlfriend's missing 10-year-old son.
THE CONFESSOR, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $25.95.) Intrigue involving a
Mossad agent and a new pope, Paul VII, follows the murder of an Israeli writer.
LATE BLOOMER, by Fern Michaels. (Atria, $24.) Aided by her grandmother, a
woman begins to recover memories of a childhood tragedy.
CROSSROADS OF TWILIGHT, by Robert Jordan. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.)
The 10th volume in the fantasy series "The Wheel of Time."
FLASHBACK, by Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $24.95.) The park ranger Anna Pigeon
looks for clues after a boat explodes off Key West.
THE CAT WHO BROUGHT DOWN THE HOUSE, by Lilian Jackson Braun.
(Putnam, $23.95.) Jim Qwilleran and his cat Koko look into a suspicious death.
PREY, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) In the Nevada desert, a team
of scientists tries to undo an experiment involving nanoparticles -- molecule-sized
robots -- that has gone disastrously wrong.
THE DANTE CLUB, by Matthew Pearl. (Random House, $24.95.) Henry
Wadsworth Longfellow, Oliver Wendell Holmes et al. hunt for a killer who has
been inspired by their translation of the "Inferno."
PATTERN RECOGNITION, by William Gibson. (Putnam, $25.95.) A brilliant
freelance marketing consultant searches for the next big fad -- and for clues to the
disappearance of her father, a retired C.I.A. man.
DROP CITY, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Viking, $25.95.) In 1970, the members of
a Northern California hippie commune that has migrated to Alaska find life there to
be very rough going.
SONS OF FORTUNE, by Jeffrey Archer. (St. Martin's, $27.95.) Twin brothers who
were separated at birth both decide to run for governor in Connecticut -- but
March 16, 2003
Non-Fiction
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
THE SAVAGE NATION, by Michael Savage. (WND/ Thomas Nelson, $24.99.) A
radio talk show host proposes to save America from "the liberal assault on our
borders, language and culture."
THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $25.95.) The tale of a
great architect (Daniel Hudson Burnham) and a serial killer (H. H. Holmes), who
were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
WHAT SHOULD I DO WITH MY LIFE? by Po Bronson. (Random House, $24.95.)
The stories of 55 people who found their calling after years of struggle.
THIS JUST IN, by Bob Schieffer. (Putnam, $26.95.) A memoir by the chief
Washington correspondent for CBS News and moderator of "Face the Nation."
USEFUL IDIOTS, by Mona Charen. (Regnery, $27.95.) The columnist and
television commentator goes on the attack against liberals.
LEADERSHIP, by Rudolph W. Giuliani with Ken Kurson. (Miramax/Hyperion,
$25.95.) The former mayor addresses subjects like the crime rate and 9/11.
GOOD TO GREAT, by Jim Collins. (HarperBusiness, $27.50.) Why some
companies thrive and others do not.
BUSH AT WAR, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Behind the scenes
at the White House as the president and his advisers responded to the 9/11
attacks.
HATRED'S KINGDOM, by Dore Gold. (Regnery, $27.95.) An Israeli diplomat who
has served as ambassador to the United Nations argues that "Saudi Arabia
supports the new global terrorism."
PIGS AT THE TROUGH, by Arianna Huffington. (Crown, $22.) How "corporate
greed and political corruption are undermining America."
THE RIGHT MAN, by David Frum. (Random House, $25.95.) A former
speechwriter for President Bush relives the first year of his administration.
OF PARADISE AND POWER, by Robert Kagan. (Knopf, $18.) A scholar analyzes
the changing relationship between Europe and the United States.
PORTRAIT OF A KILLER, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $27.95.) The crime
novelist presents evidence that the artist Walter Sickert was Jack the Ripper.
